findings:
Chest CT Findings in

2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Infections from Wuhan, China: Key Points for the Radiologist

Jeffrey P. Kanne, MD

Frequency (%)

ter, the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention commenced an investigation into the outbreak. A previously unknown coronavirus (2019 novel coronavirus [2019-nCoV]) was isolated from respiratory epithelial cells in these patients [2]. Initially confined to Wuhan, the infection has spread elsewhere, with 9720 confirmed cases in China and 106 confirmed cases in other countries— including six in the United States as of January 31, 2020 [3,4].

Seven coronaviruses are known to cause disease in humans [2,5,6]. Two strains, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East respira-

Ground-glass opacity Consolidation Crazy-paving Linear Cavitation Discrete nodules Pleural effusion Lymphadenopathy

Chest CT Findings in

2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Infections

As the number of reported cases of 2019-nCoV infection continue to increase, radiologists may encounter patients with this infection. A high index of suspicion and detailed exposure and travel history are critical to considering this diagnosis. In the correct clinical setting, bilateral ground-glass opacities or consolidation at chest imaging should prompt the radiologist to suggest 2019-nCoV as a possible diagnosis. Furthermore, a normal chest CT scan does not exclude the diagnosis of 2019-nCoV infection.

Other relationships: disclosed no relevant relationships.

CT Findings: ter, the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention commenced an investigation into the outbreak. A previously unknown coronavirus (2019 novel coronavirus [2019-nCoV]) was isolated from respiratory epithelial cells in these patients [2]. Initially confined to Wuhan, the infection has spread elsewhere, with 9720 confirmed cases in China and 106 confirmed cases in other countries— including six in the United States as of January 31, 2020 [3,4].
Seven coronaviruses are known to cause disease in humans [2,5,6]. Two strains, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East respira-
Peripheral distribution: tory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), have zoonotic origins and have been linked to outbreaks of severe respiratory illnesses in humans [6]. One of those patients still had a normal scan tom onset showed bilateral lung consolidation with rela- at short-term follow-up. Seven other patients underwent tive peripheral sparing. A radiograph obtained 3 days later follow-up CT (range, 1–4 days; mean, 2.5 days); five showed more extensive, basal predominant lung consoli- (63%) had mild progression, and two (25%) had moderdation with possible small pleural effusions correspond- ate progression.

Overall, the imaging findings reported for 2019-nCoV images from a single patient who had peripheral, bilateral are similar to those reported for SARS-CoV [11–13] and ground-glass opacity [9]. A different report of six family MERS-CoV [14,15], not surprising as the responsible members with 2019-nCoV lung infection mentions lung viruses are also coronaviruses. Given that up to 30% of opacities present on chest CT scans but lacks details on patients with 2019-nCoV infection develop acute respirapattern or distribution aside from ground-glass opacities tory distress syndrome [8], chest imaging studies showing in an asymptomatic 10-year-old boy [7]. A recent cohort study of 41 patients with confirmed 2019-nCoV infection included limited analysis of chest imaging studies.
extensive consolidation and ground-glass opacity, typical of acute lung injury, are not unexpected [16,17]. The longterm imaging features of 2019-nCoV are not yet known
All but one patient was reported to have bilateral lung but presumably will resemble those of other causes of acute involvement on chest radiographs [8]. Patients admitted lung injury.

As the number of reported cases of 2019-nCoV infection continue to increase, radiologists may encounter patients with this infection. A high index of suspicion and detailed exposure and travel history are critical to considering this diagnosis. In the correct clinical setting, bilateral ground-glass opacities or consolidation at chest imaging should prompt the radiologist to suggest 2019-nCoV as a possible diagnosis. Furthermore, a normal chest CT scan does not exclude the diagnosis of 2019-nCoV infection.

Extensive consolidation and ground-glass opacity, typical of acute lung injury, are not unexpected [16,17].

Chest CT Findings in 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Infections
In the correct clinical setting, bilateral ground-glass opacities or consolidation at chest imaging should prompt the radiologist to suggest 2019-nCoV as a possible diagnosis.
A normal chest CT scan does not exclude the diagnosis of 2019-nCoV infection.
Disclosures of Conflicts of Interest: Activities related to the present article: disclosed no relevant relationships.

Introduction: Acluster of patients with an acute severe lower respiratory tract illness linked to a seafood and live animal market was reported by public health officials in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, in December 2019 [1].
Tory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), have zoonotic origins and have been linked to outbreaks of severe respiratory illnesses in humans [6].

2019-nCoV, too, is to the intensive care unit were more likely to have larger believed to have a zoonotic origin, person-to-person trans- areas of bilateral consolidation on CT scans, whereas pamission has been documented [7].
Most patients with 2019-nCoV infection present with with milder illness were more likely to have ground-glass fever (98%), cough (76%), and myalgia or fatigue (44%).
Results: 2019-nCoV infection [10] showed three (21%) with normal CT scans, 12 (57%) with ground-glass opacity only, and six (29%) with ground-glass opacity and consolida-
Fifteen patients (71%) had two or findings of 2019-nCoV lung infection (Table).
Tial report included chest radiographs of a single patient.
Three patients (14%) had normal scans at A bedside chest radiograph obtained 8 days after symp- diagnosis.
One of those patients still had a normal scan tom onset showed bilateral lung consolidation with rela- at short-term follow-up.

A radiograph obtained 3 days later follow-up CT; five showed more extensive, basal predominant lung consoli- (63%) had mild progression, and two (25%) had moderdation with possible small pleural effusions correspond- ate progression.
Images from a single patient who had peripheral, bilateral are similar to those reported for SARS-CoV [11–13] and ground-glass opacity [9].

Given that up to 30% of opacities present on chest CT scans but lacks details on patients with 2019-nCoV infection develop acute respirapattern or distribution aside from ground-glass opacities tory distress syndrome [8], chest imaging studies showing in an asymptomatic 10-year-old boy [7].
A recent cohort study of 41 patients with confirmed 2019-nCoV infection included limited analysis of chest imaging studies.
Extensive consolidation and ground-glass opacity, typical of acute lung injury, are not unexpected [16,17].
All but one patient was reported to have bilateral lung but presumably will resemble those of other causes of acute involvement on chest radiographs [8].
Conclusion: Chest CT Findings in 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Infections
In the correct clinical setting, bilateral ground-glass opacities or consolidation at chest imaging should prompt the radiologist to suggest 2019-nCoV as a possible diagnosis.
A normal chest CT scan does not exclude the diagnosis of 2019-nCoV infection.
Disclosures of Conflicts of Interest: Activities related to the present article: disclosed no relevant relationships.
